title: Establishes the independent office of the child advocate; repealer
summary: Establishes the independent office of child advocate to ensure the protection and promotion of legal rights for youth in juvenile justice facilities; repeals certain provisions relating to the office of the ombudsman.

       Introduced  by  Sen.  PARKER -- read twice and ordered printed, and when
         printed to be committed to the Committee on Children and Families

       AN ACT to amend the executive law, in relation to the  establishment  of
         the  independent  office  of the child advocate; and repealing certain
         provisions of such law relating to the office of the ombudsman

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1. Subtitle B of title 3 of article 19-G of the executive law
    2  is REPEALED.
    3    S 2. The executive law is amended by adding a new article 19-I to read
    4  as follows:
    5                                ARTICLE 19-I
    6                  INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE
    7  SECTION 533. INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE; CREATION.
    8          534. DEFINITIONS.
    9          535. THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   10          536. DUTIES OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   11          537. POWERS OF THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   12          538. DUTY TO MAINTAIN CONFIDENTIALITY.
   13          539. ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS.
   14    S 533. INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE;  CREATION.  THERE  IS
   15  HEREBY CREATED IN THE EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, AN INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE
   16  CHILD ADVOCATE, WHICH SHALL:
   17    1.  EXAMINE,  EVALUATE  AND REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE
   18  ON:
   19    (A) PARTICULAR AND SYSTEMIC ISSUES IN PUBLICLY FUNDED JUVENILE JUSTICE
   20  PROGRAMS OVERSEEN BY THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES; AND
   21    (B) MULTI-SYSTEMIC ISSUES THAT CHILDREN IN THE JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM
   22  EXPERIENCE IN ACCESSING NEEDED SERVICES ACROSS SYSTEMS; AND

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD01331-01-1

       S. 1052                             2

    1    2. ADVOCATE FOR, AND REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR  AND  THE  LEGISLATURE  ON
    2  SUGGESTED  STATUTORY,  REGULATORY  OR  POLICY CHANGES AIMED AT IMPROVING
    3  OUTCOMES AND SERVICES FOR CHILDREN IN THE JUVENILE  JUSTICE  SYSTEM  AND
    4  THEIR FAMILIES IN NEW YORK STATE.
    5    S 534. DEFINITIONS. AS USED IN THIS ARTICLE:
    6    1. "CHILD" OR "CHILDREN" MEANS:
    7    (A) A PERSON, OR PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF EIGHTEEN; OR
    8    (B)  A  PERSON  OR  PERSONS  UNDER  THE AGE OF TWENTY-ONE WHO HAS BEEN
    9  PLACED INTO A JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITY IN THE CARE, CUSTODY, OR GUARDI-
   10  ANSHIP OF THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES OR A  LOCAL  SOCIAL
   11  SERVICES DISTRICT PURSUANT TO ARTICLE THREE OF THE FAMILY COURT ACT.
   12    2. "CHILD ADVOCATE" MEANS THE PERSON APPOINTED PURSUANT TO SUBDIVISION
   13  ONE  OF  SECTION  FIVE HUNDRED THIRTY-FIVE OF THIS ARTICLE TO DIRECT AND
   14  OVERSEE THE ACTIVITIES OF THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   15    S 535. THE CHILD ADVOCATE. 1. THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL BE AN  INDIVID-
   16  UAL  WITH  AT LEAST FIVE YEARS EXPERIENCE IN THE GENERAL SUBJECT AREA OF
   17  EITHER CHILD WELFARE, JUVENILE JUSTICE OR CHILDHOOD  BEHAVIORAL  HEALTH,
   18  WHO  SHALL  BE  APPOINTED BY THE GOVERNOR UPON THE ADVICE AND CONSENT OF
   19  THE SENATE FOR A TERM OF FIVE YEARS. THE CHILD ADVOCATE  SHALL  CONTINUE
   20  TO  HOLD  SUCH POSITION UNTIL HIS OR HER SUCCESSOR IS APPOINTED, BUT MAY
   21  BE REMOVED FROM HIS OR HER POSITION IF THE GOVERNOR SHALL DETERMINE THAT
   22  SUCH CHILD ADVOCATE HAS ABUSED HIS OR  HER  RIGHTS,  POWERS,  OR  DUTIES
   23  ESTABLISHED  PURSUANT  TO  THIS  ARTICLE OR THAT HE OR SHE HAS WILLFULLY
   24  FAILED TO CARRY OUT THE DUTIES REQUIRED BY THIS ARTICLE. THE CHILD ADVO-
   25  CATE SHALL REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR, WHO SHALL FIX THE COMPENSATION OF THE
   26  CHILD ADVOCATE WITHIN AMOUNTS APPROPRIATED THEREFOR.
   27    2. THE CHILD ADVOCATE MAY HIRE OR APPOINT PERSONS  AS  MAY  BE  DEEMED
   28  NECESSARY TO CARRY OUT THE DUTIES OF THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD
   29  ADVOCATE. THE DUTIES OF PERSONS EMPLOYED OR APPOINTED BY THE CHILD ADVO-
   30  CATE  SHALL  BE  PERFORMED UNDER THE ADVICE AND SUPERVISION OF THE CHILD
   31  ADVOCATE. PERSONS EMPLOYED OR APPOINTED BY THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE
   32  CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL BE INDIVIDUALS WITH EXPERTISE IN THE AREAS OF CHILD
   33  WELFARE, JUVENILE JUSTICE, CHILDHOOD  BEHAVIORAL  HEALTH,  FOSTER  CARE,
   34  PREVENTIVE  SERVICES,  OR  CHILD  CARE, AS EVIDENCED BY EXPERTISE IN THE
   35  FIELD, PRACTICE, ADVOCACY OR  BY  ACADEMIC  BACKGROUND,  THE  LEVEL  AND
   36  SUFFICIENCY  OF  WHICH  SHALL  BE  DETERMINED BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE. THE
   37  CHILD ADVOCATE  SHALL  FIX  THE  COMPENSATION  OF  PERSONS  EMPLOYED  OR
   38  APPOINTED BY THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE WITHIN AMOUNTS
   39  APPROPRIATED THEREFOR.
   40    S 536. DUTIES OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE. 1. THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL:
   41    (A)  EXAMINE, EVALUATE, INVESTIGATE AND REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE
   42  LEGISLATURE ON PARTICULAR AND SYSTEMIC ISSUES IN PUBLICLY  FUNDED  JUVE-
   43  NILE  JUSTICE  PROGRAMS  OVERSEEN  BY  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY
   44  SERVICES AND LOCAL SOCIAL SERVICES DISTRICTS; AND
   45    (B) EXAMINE, EVALUATE, INVESTIGATE AND REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND  THE
   46  LEGISLATURE  ON  MULTI-SYSTEMIC  ISSUES  THAT  CHILDREN  IN THE JUVENILE
   47  JUSTICE SYSTEM EXPERIENCE IN ACCESSING NEEDED SERVICES  ACROSS  SYSTEMS;
   48  AND
   49    (C)  MONITOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE POLICIES, REGULATIONS AND STAT-
   50  UTES OF STATE AGENCIES WHICH MAY BE APPLICABLE TO THE  LEGAL  RIGHTS  OF
   51  CHILDREN  IN JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITIES OVERSEEN BY THE OFFICE OF CHIL-
   52  DREN AND FAMILY SERVICES OR A LOCAL SOCIAL  SERVICES  DISTRICT,  OR  THE
   53  FAMILY OF SUCH CHILDREN; AND
   54    (D)  MONITOR  THE IMPLEMENTATION OF POLICIES, REGULATIONS AND STATUTES
   55  WHICH MAY HAVE AN IMPACT ON PUBLICLY FUNDED  JUVENILE  JUSTICE  PROGRAMS
   56  OVERSEEN BY THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES; AND

       S. 1052                             3

    1    (E)  RECOMMEND  CHANGES  IN  STATE  POLICIES, STATUTES AND REGULATIONS
    2  CONCERNING CHILDREN IN THE JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM AND THE  FAMILIES  OF
    3  SUCH CHILDREN; AND
    4    (F)  RECOMMEND  CHANGES  IN  STATE POLICIES, STATUTES, AND REGULATIONS
    5  CONCERNING PUBLICLY FUNDED JUVENILE JUSTICE PROGRAMS THAT SERVICE  CHIL-
    6  DREN  AND  FAMILIES,  ADMINISTERED  BY THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY
    7  SERVICES OR LOCAL SOCIAL SERVICES DISTRICTS; AND
    8    (G) TAKE APPROPRIATE ACTIONS AIMED AT PROMOTION OF THE RIGHTS, SAFETY,
    9  WELL-BEING, AND BEST INTERESTS OF CHILDREN IN NEW YORK STATE, INCLUDING,
   10  BUT NOT LIMITED TO, UNDERTAKING LEGISLATIVE ADVOCACY, CONDUCTING  PUBLIC
   11  HEARINGS AND MAKING PROPOSALS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE OR SYSTEMIC REFORM; AND
   12    (H)  PROVIDE ADMINISTRATIVE SUPERVISION AND OVERSIGHT TO THE INDEPEND-
   13  ENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE AND DEVOTE FULL-TIME TO THE  DUTIES  OF
   14  HIS OR HER OFFICE; AND
   15    (I)  CONDUCT PERIODIC INSPECTIONS, EVALUATIONS OR REVIEWS OF ANY JUVE-
   16  NILE JUSTICE FACILITY OPERATED BY THE  OFFICE  OF  CHILDREN  AND  FAMILY
   17  SERVICES  AT  ANY  TIME,  WITH OR WITHOUT PRIOR NOTICE. JUVENILE JUSTICE
   18  FACILITY DIRECTORS AND STAFF SHALL COOPERATE WITH SUCH INSPECTION, EVAL-
   19  UATION OR REVIEW. AN ADVOCATE SHALL HAVE THE RIGHT TO INSPECT THE  JUVE-
   20  NILE JUSTICE FACILITY, VISIT ALL AREAS AND OBSERVE ALL PARTS AND ASPECTS
   21  OF SUCH FACILITY PROGRAM; AND
   22    (J) REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE AS NEEDED, BUT NOT LESS
   23  THAN  TWICE PER YEAR. SUCH REPORT SHALL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC,
   24  UNLESS SUCH MATERIALS ARE CONFIDENTIAL PURSUANT TO  STATUTE,  AND  SHALL
   25  INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:
   26    (A)  INFORMATION  CONCERNING  THE  NUMBER AND TYPES OF REVIEWS, EVALU-
   27  ATIONS AND INVESTIGATIONS CONDUCTED BY THE  INDEPENDENT  OFFICE  OF  THE
   28  CHILD ADVOCATE; AND
   29    (B) ANY RECOMMENDATIONS BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE FOR LEGISLATIVE, REGULA-
   30  TORY, OR PUBLIC POLICY CHANGES.
   31    2.  IF  AFTER EXAMINATION PURSUANT TO SUBDIVISION ONE OF THIS SECTION,
   32  THE CHILD ADVOCATE IDENTIFIES A SYSTEMIC PROBLEM  IN  HOW  SERVICES  ARE
   33  PROVIDED TO CHILDREN IN THE CARE, CUSTODY, OR GUARDIANSHIP OF THE OFFICE
   34  OF  CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES OR A LOCAL SOCIAL SERVICES DISTRICT, BY
   35  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES, OR A LOCAL  SOCIAL  SERVICES
   36  DISTRICT,  OR  ANY  PUBLIC  OR  PRIVATE  ENTITY WHICH CONTRACTS WITH THE
   37  OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND  FAMILY  SERVICES  OR  A  LOCAL  SOCIAL  SERVICES
   38  DISTRICT  TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO SUCH CHILDREN, THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL
   39  PROVIDE SUCH OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY A WRITTEN REPORT OUTLIN-
   40  ING THE FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   41    (A) AN OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY NAMED IN  A  REPORT  BY  THE
   42  CHILD ADVOCATE AS DESCRIBED IN THIS SUBDIVISION SHALL HAVE THE OPTION TO
   43  RESPOND  IN  WRITING  TO THE CHILD ADVOCATE'S FINDINGS, PROVIDED HOWEVER
   44  THAT SUCH WRITTEN RESPONSE MUST BE ISSUED WITHIN  NINETY  DAYS  OF  SUCH
   45  OFFICE, DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY'S RECEIPT OF THE APPLICABLE REPORT BY
   46  THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   47    (B) WITHIN THIRTY DAYS AFTER THE RECEIPT OF A RESPONSE FROM AN OFFICE,
   48  DISTRICT,  AGENCY  OR ENTITY AS DESCRIBED IN THIS SUBDIVISION, THE CHILD
   49  ADVOCATE SHALL ISSUE SUCH RESPONSE, AND THE REPORT ISSUED BY  THE  CHILD
   50  ADVOCATE  PURSUANT TO THIS SUBDIVISION, TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLA-
   51  TURE.
   52    (C) IF A RESPONSE OR A WRITTEN REQUEST FOR AN ADDITIONAL  THIRTY  DAYS
   53  WITH  AN EXPLANATION IS NOT RECEIVED BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE WITHIN NINETY
   54  DAYS FROM THE DATE THAT THE CHILD ADVOCATE  SENT  SUCH  REPORT  TO  SUCH
   55  OFFICE,  DISTRICT,  AGENCY  OR  ENTITY, THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL PROVIDE
   56  SUCH REPORT TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE LEGISLATURE WITH  A  NOTICE  STATING

       S. 1052                             4

    1  THAT  SUCH  OFFICE,  DISTRICT, AGENCY OR ENTITY FAILED TO ISSUE A TIMELY
    2  WRITTEN RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
    3    S  537.  POWERS  OF  THE  INDEPENDENT  OFFICE  OF  THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
    4  NOTWITHSTANDING ANY PROVISION OF LAW OR REGULATION TO THE CONTRARY,  THE
    5  INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL HAVE ACCESS TO, INCLUDING
    6  THE  RIGHT  TO  INSPECT AND COPY, ANY RECORDS NECESSARY TO CARRY OUT ITS
    7  RIGHTS, POWERS AND DUTIES PURSUANT TO THIS ARTICLE,  INCLUDING  BUT  NOT
    8  LIMITED  TO,  PERSONNEL  RECORDS  THAT BEAR ON ANY ISSUE BEING REVIEWED,
    9  EVALUATED, OR INVESTIGATED AND RECORDS OF CHILDREN  UNDER  CARE  OF  THE
   10  JUVENILE  JUSTICE  SYSTEM  THAT BEAR ON ANY ISSUE BEING REVIEWED, EVALU-
   11  ATED, OR INVESTIGATED. THE INDEPENDENT  OFFICE  OF  THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE
   12  SHALL  ALSO HAVE THE AUTHORITY TO SUBPOENA RECORDS AND WITNESSES, AND TO
   13  CONDUCT INTERVIEWS WITH ANY PERSON NECESSARY TO CARRY  OUT  ITS  RIGHTS,
   14  POWERS AND DUTIES PURSUANT TO THIS ARTICLE, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO
   15  STAFF AND CHILDREN UNDER CARE OF THE JUVENILE JUSTICE SYSTEM.
   16    S  538. DUTY TO MAINTAIN CONFIDENTIALITY. ALL RECORDS OF THE INDEPEND-
   17  ENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE PERTAINING TO THE  FULFILLMENT  OF  THE
   18  CHILD ADVOCATE'S RIGHTS, POWERS AND DUTIES PURSUANT TO THIS ARTICLE, AND
   19  ALL  RECORDS  OBTAINED BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL BE KEPT CONFIDENTIAL,
   20  PROVIDED HOWEVER, THAT LIMITED INFORMATION CONTAINED IN SUCH RECORDS MAY
   21  BE RELEASED BY THE CHILD ADVOCATE, IF APPROPRIATE, AND UPON APPROVAL  OF
   22  THE  CHILD ADVOCATE, SO LONG AS THE INFORMATION TO BE RELEASED WOULD NOT
   23  IDENTIFY THE CHILD OR CHILDREN THE CHILD ADVOCATE  WAS  SERVING  OR  THE
   24  NAMES OF THE PARENTS OR SIBLINGS OF SUCH CHILD OR CHILDREN.
   25    S  539.  ADDITIONAL  PROVISIONS.  1.  THE STATE SHALL PROTECT AND HOLD
   26  HARMLESS ANY PERSON EMPLOYED OR APPOINTED BY THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE,  FROM
   27  FINANCIAL  LOSS  AND  EXPENSE,  INCLUDING  LEGAL FEES AND COSTS, IF ANY,
   28  ARISING OUT OF ANY CLAIM, DEMAND OR SUIT FOR DAMAGES RESULTING FROM ACTS
   29  OR OMISSIONS COMMITTED IN THE DISCHARGE OF HIS OR HER RIGHTS, POWERS AND
   30  DUTIES WITHIN THE SCOPE OF HIS OR HER EMPLOYMENT  OR  APPOINTMENT  WHICH
   31  MAY  CONSTITUTE  NEGLIGENCE  BUT WHICH ACTS ARE NOT WANTON, MALICIOUS OR
   32  GROSSLY NEGLIGENT AS DETERMINED BY A COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDICTION.
   33    2. NO STATE OR LOCAL  AGENCY,  DEPARTMENT,  OFFICE,  OR  ENTITY  SHALL
   34  DISCHARGE,  OR  IN  ANY  MANNER  DISCRIMINATE  OR RETALIATE AGAINST, ANY
   35  PERSON WHO IN GOOD FAITH MAKES A COMPLAINT TO, OR COOPERATES  WITH,  THE
   36  CHILD  ADVOCATE  IN  A REVIEW OR EVALUATION CONDUCTED BY THE CHILD ADVO-
   37  CATE. NO EMPLOYEE OF ANY STATE OR LOCAL DEPARTMENT OR OFFICE OR  OF  ANY
   38  PRIVATE  ENTITY SHALL RETALIATE AGAINST ANY PERSON WHO MAKES A COMPLAINT
   39  TO, OR WHO COOPERATES WITH THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD  ADVOCATE
   40  IN  A  REVIEW,  INVESTIGATION OR EVALUATION CONDUCTED BY THE INDEPENDENT
   41  OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE.
   42    3. ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD  ADVOCATE
   43  SHALL  REMAIN  CONFIDENTIAL.  ANY  COMPLAINT FILED BY A YOUTH OR A STAFF
   44  MEMBER OF A JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITY WITH THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE
   45  CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL REMAIN CONFIDENTIAL. ALL YOUTH RESIDING IN A  JUVE-
   46  NILE  JUSTICE  FACILITY  SHALL BE PERMITTED REASONABLE ACCESS TO A TELE-
   47  PHONE TO MAKE A TOLL FREE CALL OR SHALL BE SUPPLIED WRITING MATERIALS IN
   48  ORDER TO WRITE LETTERS TO THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE
   49  UPON  THE YOUTH'S REQUEST. ANY COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN SUCH YOUTH AND THE
   50  INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL REMAIN  CONFIDENTIAL  AND
   51  SHALL  NOT BE MONITORED BY ANY MEMBER OF THE JUVENILE JUSTICE FACILITY'S
   52  STAFF.
   53    4. THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD  ADVOCATE  MAY  APPLY  FOR  AND
   54  ACCEPT  GRANTS, GIFTS AND BEQUESTS OF FUNDS FROM PRIVATE INDIVIDUALS AND
   55  FOUNDATIONS FOR THE PURPOSE OF CARRYING OUT STUDIES UNDER THIS  ARTICLE.

       S. 1052                             5

    1  THE  FUNDS  SHALL  BE EXPENDED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PROVISIONS OF SUCH
    2  GRANT, GIFT OR BEQUEST.
    3    5.  THE  CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL TAKE ALL POSSIBLE ACTIONS INCLUDING, BUT
    4  NOT LIMITED TO, CONDUCTING PROGRAMS  OF  PUBLIC  EDUCATION,  UNDERTAKING
    5  LEGISLATIVE  ADVOCACY AND MAKING PROPOSALS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE CORRECTION
    6  OR REFORM AND FORMAL LEGAL ACTION, IN ORDER TO  SECURE  AND  ENSURE  THE
    7  LEGAL, CIVIL AND SPECIAL RIGHTS OF CHILDREN.
    8    6.  THE  CHILD  ADVOCATE  SHALL TAKE THE APPROPRIATE STEPS TO MAKE THE
    9  EXISTENCE AND AVAILABILITY OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE WIDELY KNOWN, BY APPRO-
   10  PRIATE AND ACTIVE MEANS, TO CHILDREN AND ADULTS.
   11    7. THE CHILD ADVOCATE SHALL CREATE INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS  FOR  CHIL-
   12  DREN  REGARDING  THE  RIGHTS  OF  CHILDREN  WHEN  THEY  ARE IN DETENTION
   13  CENTERS, FACILITIES OPERATED  BY  THE  OFFICE  OF  CHILDREN  AND  FAMILY
   14  SERVICES,  JAILS, OR PRISONS AND THE METHODS AND ASSISTANCE AVAILABLE TO
   15  ENFORCE THOSE RIGHTS.
   16    S 3. Subdivision 16 of section 501 of the executive law, as renumbered
   17  by chapter 170 of the laws of 1994, is renumbered subdivision 17  and  a
   18  new subdivision 16 is added to read as follows:
   19    16.  THE  COMMISSIONER  OF  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES
   20  SHALL PROMULGATE REGULATIONS REQUIRING  THAT  NO  SERVICES,  FACILITIES,
   21  ENTITIES  OR  PROGRAMS  UNDER THE JURISDICTION OF THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN
   22  AND FAMILY SERVICES SHALL RESTRICT OR  PROHIBIT  ACCESS  TO  FACILITIES,
   23  RECORDS  OR  INDIVIDUALS TO THE INDEPENDENT OFFICE OF THE CHILD ADVOCATE
   24  UPON REQUEST, UNLESS  THE  DISCLOSURE  OF  SUCH  RECORDS  ARE  OTHERWISE
   25  PROHIBITED BY FEDERAL LAW OR REGULATION.
   26    S 4. This act shall take effect April 1, 2012; provided, however, that
   27  effective immediately, the addition, amendment and/or repeal of any rule
   28  or regulation necessary for the implementation of this act on its effec-
   29  tive  date  are  authorized  and directed to be made and completed on or
   30  before the effective date.
